definitions.definition: Word for word , exactly as stated.

subdefinitions.definition: Without overstatement or understatement, or false or misleading words.
examples: He's prone to exaggeration, so don't take what he says literally .
There are literally millions of individual pieces of space debris orbiting Earth.

subdefinitions.definition: With phrasings that might normally be used or understood as figurative: truly ; not figuratively ; not as an idiom or metaphor .
examples: When I saw on the news that there would be no school tomorrow because of the snowstorm, I literally jumped for joy , and hit my head on the ceiling fan.
I didn't have time to repair the wall, so I literally just papered over the cracks .

subdefinitions.definition: Draws attention to a pun or other wordplay involving an idiom.
examples: My daughter's pet rabbit had babies, and now we've literally got rabbits coming out of our ears .

subdefinitions.definition: Used as a general intensifier or dramatiser, sometimes tending towards a meaningless filler.
examples: I had no idea, so I was literally guessing.
I was literally having breakfast when she arrived.
She was literally like, "What?", and I was literally like, "Yeah".

subdefinitions.definition: Used as an intensifier with statements or terms that are in fact meant figuratively and not word for word as stated: virtually , so to speak .
examples: He was so surprised, he literally jumped twenty feet in the air.
On 9/11 people were literally glued to their TV sets.
People can't even express their opinions freely in this country any more. Literally 1984!

definitions.definition: Used as a generic downtoner : just , merely .
examples: It's not even hard⁠ to make—you literally just put it in the microwave for five minutes and it's done.
It won't take me long to get back, 'cause the store's literally two blocks away.

main_definition: Word for word , exactly as stated.
secondary_definitions: ( colloquial ) Used as a generic downtoner : just , merely .
